work.p: Handwritten notes and corrections on a printed copy of the poem "O Captain! My Captain!" first published November 4, 1865. On the verso is a small letter from Whitman to the publishers of the Riverside Literature Series concerning the corrections to be made to this printed version of the poem.

titleStmt.title: O Captain! My Captain!
a machine readable transcription

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive.

notesStmt.note: The handwritten corrections to this printed copy were probably added in 1888; the note on the verso, which relates to the poem, is dated February 9, 1888.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: O Captain! My Captain!
bibl.orgName: Walt Whitman Collection, The Library of Congress
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: O CAPTAIN! my captain! our fearful trip is done; ;
The ship has weathered every wrack, the prize we sought is won; ;
The port is near, the bells I hear, the people exalting,

While follow eyes the steady keel, the vessel grim and daring,
But O heart! heart! heart!
Leave you not the little spot,
O the bleeding drops of red ,!
Where on the deck my captain lies,
Fallen cold and dead.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Rise up! for you the flag is flung, for you the bugle trills;

For you bouquets and ribboned wreaths, for you the shores a-crowd-
ing;

For you they call, the swaying mass, their eager faces turning,
O captain! dear father!
This arm
I push beneath you
beneath your head;
It is some dream that on the deck
You've fallen cold and dead.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: My captain does not answer, his lips are pale and still;
My father does not feel my arm, he has no pulse nor will.

But the ship
t
T
he ship is anchored safe and sound, its voyage closed and done;

From fearful trip the victor ship comes in with object won!
Exult, O shores! and ring, O bells!
But I, with silent tread,
Walk the spot my captain lies
Fallen cold and dead.

note.p: Thank you for the little books, No. 32 "Riverside Literature Series"— Somehow you have got a couple of bad perversions in "O Captain", & I send you a corrected sheet—
